Want to craft it? Here is some guidance:

0:15 SHAPING THE TORSO -

1:11 ARMS - Twisting the plastic really worked well.

2:03 PUTTING ON THE ARMS - Ignite the arms connection point then hold it close to the torso for a while to heat it up. Then stick it in, wiggle it around for a moment and then keep it still until the plastic hardens.

2:59 BASE - You can also attach the elemental to a traditional base of your choice. Stick a toothpick or needle into the elemental and attach it to the base you are using.

3:36 MELDING THE ELEMENTAL TO THE BASE - make sure that the fuse is thick enough for the miniature to be durable. The miniature I made is really durable. I could throw it at the wall and nothing would ever happen.

3:45 BASE PAINT - Some crevices can be hard to get paint into, be careful not to miss some areas.
 
4:20 BRIGHTER BLUE PAINT -

4:27 PALE BLUE HIGHLIGHTS - With a smaller brush you can paint any protruding details much better than with the bad brush I used.

4:51 WHITE HIGHLIGHTS - Some areas will be bumpier and chaotic looking, add more white to these areas to create an illusion of foaming water.

5:06 BASE DETAILS WITH GREY - You could also paint some of the bumps into stones by putting on a thicker coat of dark grey followed by a lighter highlight.

5:17 PROJECT SHOWCASE - I'm really happy how easy this project is and how nice it turned out. What do you think? Have you crafted anything similar? Thanks for any feedback.
title: Cheap Water Elemental Miniature for D&D (Craft it Yourself)
